Submodules¶

battleships.components module¶

Module containing components of the game Battleships

battleships.components.check_game_over(username: str, players: dict) → bool¶

Check if the game is over for a specific player.

Keyword arguments: username – username of the player players – dictionary containing the game data of each player

battleships.components.create_battleships(filename: str = 'battleships.txt') → dict[str, int]¶

Reads the text file and returns battleships as a dictionary

Keyword arguments: filename – name of file containing battleship data (default “battleships.txt”)

battleships.components.generate_starting_position(board: list[list[None]], direction: int, length: int) → list[int, int]¶

Generated valid starting position depending on size of board and the direction and length of ship

battleships.components.initialise_board(size: int = 10) → list[list[None]]¶

Initialises a board of size * size

Keyword arguments: size – the size of the board (default 10, range: 5-10)

battleships.components.is_position_occupied(board: list[list], col: int, row: int, direction: int, length: int) → bool¶

Checks if ship can fit and returns True or False

battleships.components.place_battleships(board: list[list[None]], ships: dict[str, int], algorithm: str = 'simple') → list[list]¶

Places battleships onto the board and returns it

Keyword arguments: board – a list of lists containing None ships – a dictionary containing each ship and its length algorithm – determines the algorithm used to place ships (default “simple”)

battleships.components.place_battleships_custom(board: list[list[None]], battleships: dict[str, int]) → list[list]¶

Custom algorithm of battleships using placement.json

battleships.components.place_battleships_random(board: list[list[None]], battleships: dict[str, int]) → list[list]¶

Places battleships randomly onto the board

battleships.components.place_battleships_simple(board: list[list[None]], battleships: dict[str, int]) → list[list]¶

Places a battleship on each row

battleships.components.print_player_board(board: list[list]) → None¶

Prints out player’s resulting board.

Keyword arguments: players – a dictionary containing player data username – the username of the player
